column1: Ust-Kut (Russian: Усть-Кут) is a town and the administrative center of Ust-Kutsky District in Irkutsk Oblast
column4: the administrative center of the oblast. Located on a western loop of the Lena River
column5: the town spreads out for over 20 kilometers (12 mi) along the left bank
column6: near the point where the Kuta River joins from the west. Population: 45

column1: == Etymology ==
The town's name means "the mouth of the Kuta River" in Russian
column2: with the name "Kuta" coming from an Evenk word meaning "peat bog".

column1: == History ==
It was founded in 1631 by Siberian Cossack ataman Ivan Galkin
column2: who built an ostrog (fort) there. The fort's military importance declined in the latter half of the 17th century; however
column3: the settlement was increasingly important as a river port
column4: becoming one of the main starting points for trade along the Lena.

column1: Mineral springs to the west of the town were reportedly discovered as early as the 17th century by Yerofey Khabarov and a spa was built at the site in 1925.
In the early 20th century Ust-Kut served as a destination for political exiles

column2: the railway from Tayshet reached Ust-Kut. The town thus became the first and only river port on the Lena served by the railway and an important railhead through which cargoes could travel to and from the locations along the Lena
column3: such as most of Yakutia. Ust-Kut was granted town status in 1954
column4: with the merger of the original settlement of Ust-Kut and the river port suburb of Osetrovo.Ust-Kut remained the end of the line until 1974
column5: when construction work started to extend the railway
column6: now known as the Baikal–Amur Mainline
column7: east toward Lake Baikal and beyond. The town became the headquarters of the construction of the western section of the BAM.

column1: == Administrative and municipal status ==
Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Ust-Kut serves as the administrative center of Ust-Kutsky District
column3: to which it is directly subordinated. As a municipal division
column5: together with the selo of Turuka in Ust-Kutsky District
column6: is incorporated within Ust-Kutsky Municipal District as Ust-Kutskoye Urban Settlement.

column1: == Economy and infrastructure ==
Ust-Kut's economy relies mainly on its position as a transport hub
column2: with the connection of road and rail transport with river traffic on the Lena. During the summer months
column3: passenger ferries depart downriver from Ust-Kut to Yakutsk and Tiksi. There is a road bridge over the river in Ust-Kut.

column1: There are also shipyards and food production in the town.
Ust-Kut is spread along the Baikal–Amur Mainline with multiple stations

column2: located 9 kilometers (5.6 mi) northwest of the town center.
